answers.answer: Yes because of the diabetes and the increased incidence of glaucoma, macular degeneration and other problems you have have you need to see a physician-ophthalmologist.If you want to go to Lenscrafters or a limited scope non-physician optometrist for a refraction that's fine but don't mistake it for a medical eye examaination.JCH III MD

question: I am 61 years old.  I have type II diabetes which is under control with 500 mg of metformin daily.  I have an astigmatism and wear bifocals.  My current glasses seem to be working fine, but they are falling apart, so it is time for me to replace them.  And it's also time for me to have another exam with my eyes dilated.  I have found that optometrists for some reason seem to do a better job of prescribing glasses that work for me.  I know that they too can do a dilated eye exam.  I am wondering if there is any reason it would be preferable to see an opthamologist rather than an optometrist for my eye exam.Thanks so much.
title: Eye exam -- optometrist or opthalmologist?
